entry.title: SAP 分析云新增提醒功能，助您轻松管理数据更改日志
entry.content:
在已经发布的2025 年 QRC3 版本中，SAP 分析云全新推出“数据更改日志通知”功能，可在日志规模演变成问题前，第一时间发出提醒，让维护计划环境的健康更轻松。 

概述   

您现在可以配置提醒，当数据更改日志达到指定大小时主动通知您。这一点在多人协作的大型计划环境中尤其实用——持续的计划操作与频繁发布极易导致数据更改日志大小快速增长。 

借助这些提醒，您将获得： 

  • 模型健康状况的更高透明度   
  • 在问题出现前主动缩减日志大小的控制权 
  • 避免因日志过大而导致发布受阻的频繁中断 

配置管理   

管理通知配置   

具备相关权限的管理员或用户可通过以下路径配置数据更改日志提醒：   

系统 > 管理 > 通知 > 数据更改日志通知 

在这里，您可以：   

  • 自定义阈值大小   
  • 选择通知方式（应用内、电子邮件或两者）   
  • 指定需要接收通知的人员 

提示：为避免打扰用户，建议将阈值至少设为 60%，默认值为 80%。 

电子邮件通知的用户首选项设置 

对于“数据更改日志”对象类型具有“删除”权限的用户，或被手动添加到自定义收件人列表中的用户，可通过以下路径管理个人邮件首选项： 

个人资料设置 > 用户首选项 > 数据更改日志通知 

在这里，用户可以根据需要开启或关闭电子邮件通知。 

结果 

当任意模型的数据更改日志达到设定阈值时，系统会自动触发通知。 

当您收到通知时，建议尽快缩小日志大小，以免在发布数据时受到干扰。您可以导航到“数据更改日志”来执行此操作，借助灵活的筛选条件快速定位并删除日志记录；如需留档，可先将记录导出备份。 

结论 

借助这一全新的通知功能，您可以更有效地监控数据更改日志的健康状态，保障系统持续稳定运行。 

 

原文作者：Sarau 

原文链接：https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/new-alert-helps-you-manage-data-change-logs-easily-in-sac-analytics-cloud/ba-p/14152401

entry.title: Dynamically setting chart positions based on measure values
entry.content:
The 4 KPIs (numeric point charts) are dynamically positioned left to right based on the measure value they contain.
  Highest on the left , lowest at the far right.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Setup overview
1. Script variable: 'charts'   type: chart    array: true

2. Onitialisation Script

// populate the dropdown with members of the sales manager dimension
var mem=Chart_1.getDataSource().getMembers("Sales_Manager__5w3m5d06b5");
Dropdown_1.addItem('All');
for (var i=0;i<mem.length;i++)
	{Dropdown_1.addItem(mem[i].id,mem[i].description);}
Dropdown_1.setSelectedKey('All');

//populate the charts script variable with all charts in the story
charts=Application.getWidgets({type:WidgetType.Chart});


3. Dropdown_1 onSelect Script

var key=this.getSelectedKey();
for(var i=0;i<charts.length;i++)	{charts[i].getDataSource().removeDimensionFilter("Sales_Manager__5w3m5d06b5");
	 if(key!=='All') {	 charts[i].getDataSource().setDimensionFilter("Sales_Manager__5w3m5d06b5",key);}}

Timer_1.start(1);

4. Timer_1  onTimeout Script

// re-order charts high to low - left to right

// Step 1: Set up two typed arrays
var chartNames = ArrayUtils.create(Type.Chart);  // chart.getName()
var chartValues = ArrayUtils.create(Type.number); // converted rawValue

// Step 2: Populate both arrays
for (var ia = 0; ia < charts.length; ia++) {
    var name = charts[ia];
    var raw = charts[ia].getDataSource().getResultSet()[0][Alias.MeasureDimension].rawValue;
    var value = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(raw);

    chartNames.push(name);
    chartValues.push(value);
}

// Step 3: Bubble sort both arrays together — high to low
for (var i = 0; i < chartValues.length - 1; i++) {
    for (var j = 0; j < chartValues.length - i - 1; j++) {
        if (chartValues[j] < chartValues[j + 1]) {
            // Swap values
            var tempVal = chartValues[j];
            chartValues[j] = chartValues[j + 1];
            chartValues[j + 1] = tempVal;

            // Swap corresponding chart names
            var tempName = chartNames[j];
            chartNames[j] = chartNames[j + 1];
            chartNames[j + 1] = tempName;
        }
    }
}

// Define starting position and spacing
var leftPos = 50;         // Starting X position
var spacingGap = 50;      // Gap between charts

// Reposition each chart based on the previous chart's width
for (var iz = 0; iz < chartNames.length; iz++) {
    var chart = chartNames[iz];

    // Set chart left position
    chart.getLayout().setLeft(leftPos);

    // Update leftPos for the next chart
    var chartWidth = chart.getLayout().getWidth().value; // Get current chart width
    leftPos = leftPos + chartWidth + spacingGap;
}

The Chart sorting is placed in a Timer as we need to ensure the data has fully refreshed before trying to retrieve the values and apply the chart sort.

entry.title: Easier Integration of SAP CIS with BDC (SAC, DSP, BDCC) with a new Identity Provider Administration
entry.content:
Overview

SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) are a group of services which enable you to integrate identity and access management between systems. The goal is to provide a seamless single sign-on experience across systems while ensuring that system and data access are secure.

CIS provides several out-of-the-box features that your BDC Components and Non-BDC SAC/Datasphere do not have. 

The new IDP Admin tool will be turned on sometime in Q3. We will have a phased deployment strategy on different landscapes.

 

Why should we integrate with IAS?

Integration with SAP CIS will solve many of the identity challenges facing BDC and Non-BDC tenants. Over the years, we've had a number of influence requests asking for features related to identity in SAC and Datasphere. With a deeper integration with CIS, we can tackle many of those influence requests.

Here are just some of the benefits you will receive with integration with CIS: 

  • Conditional Authentication allows you to create users to authenticate into SAC/DSP without needing to create the user in your corporate identity provider
  • Moves the Groups=sac requirement onto IAS, instead of your corporate IDP
  • Supports multiple corporate Identity Providers
  • Single IAS can be used for SuccessFactors and then BDC
  • Improved Monitoring and Auditing
  • Improved Security in which you can use SAML or OpenID Connect
  • Future proofing as most enhancements to authentication will be made to IAS

To make it easier to "bundle" with CIS, we have updated our Identity Provisioning Administration Tool (IDP-Admin). 

In this blog, I'll show you how to do this step by step

Controlled Release

We are enabling the new IDP Admin tool in a controlled release. More details are here:

PhasesLandscapesDateBDC Products ImpactedStatus
Phase 1JP30, BR30, SA31Week of Sept 8th 2025SAC, DSPComplete
Phase 2AP30, BR20, IL30, SA30, US21, CH20Week of Sept 22nd 2025SAC, DSPComplete
Phase 3US30, AP12, CA10, IN30, EU11, AP11, EU30Week of Oct 13th 2025SAC, DSPNot started
Phase 4BR10, JP10, AP10, US20, US10, EU20, EU10Week of Nov 3rd 2025SAC, DSP, BDCNot Started
     

Getting Started

  • Persona: Administrator - You are the System Owner of tenant (SAC, DSP or BDCC)
  • Terminology: When referring to BDC Components or BDC, we are referring to SAP Analytics Cloud, Datasphere and Databricks. Although our example is coming out of SAP Analytics Cloud.  
  • The bundling tool is also available for Non-BDC SAC and Datasphere. In general, you may see this grouped in with BDC as the workflows are the same. 

How to do it?

In the below example, I'll cover the most common scenario our customers are dealing with. Your SAC or Datasphere is currently configured with your Corporate IDP directly.  

CIS Integration with your Corporate Identity Provider

In tenants where you are already using your corporate IDP with SAC/DSP/BDCC or you intend on using your corporate IDP, follow these steps. 

 

  1. Go to System > Administration > Security and scroll down to click on Launch Identity Provider Administration Tool
  2. Logon to Identity Provider Administration Tool (IDP Admin) using the System Owner user. If you don't have an account, click Register to create a new account. 
  3. Once logged in, you will see a tile representing the BDC Component (either SAC, DSP or BDCC).

    In our example, we have an SAC system. 

     


    From the context menu, Repair IdP will allow you to revert back to the default IDP or update the IDP metadata.


    For bundling, please select Add SAP Cloud Identity Services
    ** Note down the Tenant Type as this will be important in a few steps **

  4. The next screen will show you a list of all CIS tenants that you have deployed. You are entitled to Production and Test CIS tenants. If an IAS tenant is already used by another tenant like SuccessFactors or Ariba, this will appear on the list.  In addition, if you have purchased an IAS separately, it will also appear on this list. 



    As a best practice, it is recommended you select the IAS tenant that matches your tenant type from the Tile (in Step 3) 

    If you do not have any CIS provisioned yet, the Provision New SAP Cloud Identity Services Tenant button is enabled. This will provision a IAS which you can then bundle to.

  5. Input the System Owner details

  6. The last step is a summary of actions. 



    Click Finish
  7. CIS will be provisioned with your current tenant. This step does NOT change over the authentication source quite yet.




    Success!

    Clicking Continue will bring you to the final set up stage which is to validate and turn on authentication. In our case, since we are planning on integration our corporate IDP solution, we will click Close. 

  8. Log into CIS and go to Applications & Resources > Applications. You will see a new entry representing the BDC tenant that was just bundled.

    ** Note although the application has been created and some pre-configuration has been done, the authentication has not switched over to IAS yet. **

  9. The next step is an important step because we are going to use the same corporate IdP as before. To do this, follow these steps here: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/create-corporate-idp-in-administration-console?version=Cloud 

  10. Ensure that the Application's default authenticating Identity Provider is set to the corporate identity provider
  11. Check the Corporate Identity Providers in IAS to make sure "Use Identity Authentication user store" is enabled. This will make sure that the assertions contain the data needed by SAC/DSP/BDCC
  12. Now that you have configured your corporate IdP, it's time to finish the configuration and switch over the authentication.
    Go back to IDP Admin and then go to the Tile. 

    You can see the tile still says it is pending. Simply click on the
  13. Select an attribute type (default Email), provide the subject name identifier and select dynamic user creation if desired.



    **Note: Dynamic User creation will create new users during the logon time.
    For instance, I send a story to Sarah in SAC. Sarah has never used SAC before. She clicks on the link and she is prompted for her corporate portal login. A SAC user is created for Sarah and her user will now appear in System > Users. Sarah is now able to view the story. 


  14. The next step requires you open a new tab in incognito mode and use the validation URL. Make sure any existing Incognito windows signed into SAC are closed before opening the new one. 



    Log onto the tenant and then you should see:

    Close the tab

  15. Go back to the previous window and select validate login:




  16. Review the settings and then click Finish



     

  17. The following success message should appear: 


     

  18. The tile has now been updated. 
  19. You have now completed the bundling exercise. You can now take advantage of the amazing features that IAS brings. Find all the documentation here: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services

 

Quick Q&A

 

Q: I have set up my corporate IDP with IAS, but I want to authenticate into SAC or Datasphere with an alternate user?  How do I do that?

A: We refer to this as Conditional Authentication which can be configured in IAS. Create a rule specifically for a email domain or a group to use the Identity Authentication (local IAS user) instead of the corporate IDP.  More details here 

Q: How do I set up multiple Corporate IDP's?

A: Add a second IDP through IAS > Identity Providers > Corporate Identity Providers. After that, in the IAS application, add conditional authentication to support multiple IDP's based on email domain or groups.

Q: Does having multiple Corporate IDPs impact licensing for SAC?

A: No it should not impact licensing as the license thresholds are based on SAC Users that are created in the system. 

Q: How will a greenfield situation work where a tenant is new and has no users

A: The steps for greenfield will nearly be the same. At a high level, you would still go to IDP Admin and trigger the bundling. After the bundling step is done, you can configure the corporate IDP or just choose to leave it IAS as the main identity provider.

entry.title: Implementing SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction and Overview

This blog presents an end-to-end architecture for SAP Emarsys Loyalty, bringing together loyalty program design, omnichannel engagement, and closed-loop financial posting to strengthen repeat purchases and customer lifetime value.

It provides a structured view of how the solution is organized—covering applications, modules, and data objects and illustrates core processes such as onboarding, plan and tier-based accrual, voucher or points redemption, and service-driven adjustments.

Additionally, it explains how segmentation, personalization tokens, and analytics with Datasphere and SAC will be leveraged to operationalize loyalty programs and measure outcomes across channels.

Architecture

The following reference architecture explains how SAP Emarsys Loyalty can be implemented with other SAP solutions, though it may vary for different customer implementations depending on the systems they use.              Emarsys Loyalty Architecture

Based on this reference architecture, the following SAP solutions are proposed for integration with SAP Emarsys Loyalty.

  • SAP S/4 HANA will handle loyalty points earned through transactions such as sales orders and retail purchases, with real-time posting of point accruals and redemptions to ensure financial accuracy.
  • Web or mobile apps may be used to let customers check their loyalty activity, view offers and exclusive access, and track points, tiers, and plans through a digital wallet.
  • SAP Service Cloud will give customer service agents a complete view of the loyalty profile, including tier, balance, and past redemptions, enabling them to resolve issues like missing points, redemption problems, or upgrades.
  • Campaign channels such as email, mobile, and web will be used to run loyalty campaigns, encourage purchases, share offers, and update customers on their tier or points status.
  • Finally, SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud will provide reports, dashboards, and stories related to loyalty performance.

 

End-to-End Loyalty process flow

Customer Registration and Loyalty on Boarding

Customer registration and loyalty onboarding start with joining the program to enjoy benefits from purchases and activities. New customers can enroll during registration, while existing customers can join anytime. For both, a hash ID must be generated and assigned to their record before they can join. Enrollment can be done through mobile apps, websites, or POS systems.

 

Points accrual

Points accrual allows customers to earn loyalty points and benefits based on their purchases and activities. For purchases, data is sent from SAP ERP to Smart Insight and then to Loyalty, where points and benefits are calculated based on the customer’s plan and tier. The confirmed points are then sent back to SAP ERP/S4 HANA for financial posting.

 

Points Redemption:

 At checkout, customers can either use an existing voucher they have already claimed or pay directly with their points. When a voucher is claimed, the points are redeemed at that time. If customers pay directly with points, the points are deducted from their balance, and the financial postings are then processed in SAP S/4HANA. 

 

Customer Service Support scenarios for points

Customer service support for points comes into play when customers raise issues such as missing rewards, incorrect deductions, or other loyalty-related queries. A ticket or case is created in the Service Cloud, where an agent can view the customer’s loyalty profile through an interface. The agent can then adjust points or tiers as needed, and each change triggers the corresponding financial postings in SAP S/4HANA

 

Loyalty Segmentation, Personalization and Campaigns

 Loyalty segmentation, personalization, and campaigns are managed using relational data templates to create customer segments. These segments are then used across different channels to run targeted campaigns. Personalization tokens ensure that campaign messages are customized for each customer before being sent.

 

Loyalty reports and Dashboards

Loyalty data is shared with Google Cloud Platform through open data views. These views can be used to build models within SAP Datasphere, and the models are then consumed in SAP Analytics Cloud for reporting and analysis.

 

Conclusion

This blog lays out an architecture blueprint for SAP Emarsys Loyalty, showing how businesses can run smarter, more connected loyalty programs by combining customer engagement, financial accuracy, and personalized experiences. It supports the complete loyalty lifecycle from enrollment, earning and burning points, to customer service and reporting, while integrating seamlessly with SAP systems such as S/4HANA, Service Cloud, and Analytics Cloud, along with mobile and web apps. This ensures customers enjoy a smooth, rewarding experience across all touchpoints, while businesses strengthen retention, boost revenue, and build lasting brand loyalty.

Stay tuned for upcoming posts where we will share business processes, customizations, and technical insights—highlighting how each component comes together to deliver a seamless loyalty experience.

To be continued…

entry.title: How to add BW Last Data Update field to SAP Analytics Cloud + Datasphere (SAP Note 2706430)
entry.content:
Summary

SAP Note 2706430 - How to get latest datasource update/refresh data date/time in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)?
Improvement Request 219791 - Dynamic text for datasource last refresh date and time

When customers move from SAP BW to SAP Datasphere + SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), a common ask is: “Where’s the BW-style Last Data Update field?” SAC’s dynamic-text / model metadata doesn’t reliably supply a full source refresh timestamp for all scenarios, so the recommended pattern is to capture the refresh timestamp at the source (or during the import/persistence flow), expose it through a small tracking table / SQL view and then surface it in the SAC story via dynamic text on a small analytic model. This post shows a practical, production-ready approach and pitfalls to watch out for.

 

Introduction

Customers migrating from SAP Business Warehouse (BW) often miss the metadata field “Last Data Update” that shows when a dataset was last refreshed. BW had the table RSDINFOPROVDATA to store that info for each BW data cube— in Datasphere/HANA + SAC we can recreate this pattern. This post explains a reproducible approach:

  1. discover the underlying tables/views for your Analytical Model (lineage),
  2. create a small refresh-tracking table,
  3. populate it during your delta-import, import or persistence flows
  4. combine tracked records using a SQL View, and
  5. expose it to SAC using a tiny analytic model
  6. consume the information using a dynamic text filed in your story

 

1) Find the source objects 

Use Datasphere / HANA lineage features (calculation view lineage) or the HANA system view OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES to find which base tables feed your Analytical Model / calculation view. Example SQL to use in HANA Database Explore:

SELECT TOP 1000000
  "BASE_DATABASE_SCHEMA_NAME",
  "BASE_DATABASE_NAME",
  "BASE_SCHEMA_NAME",
  "BASE_OBJECT_NAME",
  "BASE_OBJECT_TYPE",
  "DEPENDENT_DATABASE_NAME",
  "DEPENDENT_SCHEMA_NAME",
  "DEPENDENT_OBJECT_NAME",
  "DEPENDENT_OBJECT_TYPE",
  "DEPENDENCY_TYPE"
FROM "PUBLIC"."OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES"
WHERE "DEPENDENT_SCHEMA_NAME" = '<SPACE_NAME>'
  AND "DEPENDENT_OBJECT_NAME" LIKE '<Analytical_Model_Name>%'
  AND "BASE_OBJECT_TYPE" = 'TABLE';

This gives you the base tables that the model depends on. if you have multiple analyitc models it is a best practise to group these where possible.

 

2) Create a tracking table (“RSDINFOPROVDATA” equivalent)

Create a small table to capture last refresh timestamps for each tracked table. I recommend to enable it for Delta capture.

When Importing data across different spaces you need to create multiple tables since shared tables are read only. These tables can later be joined in step 4.

 

3) Populate the tracking table during data import/ persistence

Pattern A — Import using delta tables

If you have delta tables (e.g., <TABLE>_Delta), use a transformation flow to compute the latest timestamp and upsert it into 1TL_Last_Delta.

Example SQL used by a transformation flow:

SELECT t."View_Name", t."Last_Refresh" FROM "<DELTA TABLE>" t 
WHERE "View_Name" IN ('<TRACKED TABLE 1>', '<TRACKED TABLE 2>', '<TRACKED TABLE 3>', '<TRACKED TABLE 4>') 
UNION ALL 
SELECT 'MAX_<TRACKED TABLE 1>_<TRACKED TABLE 2>' AS "View_Name", MAX(t."Last_Refresh") AS "Last_Refresh" FROM "<DELTA TABLE>" t 
WHERE t."View_Name" IN ( '<TRACKED TABLE 1>', '<TRACKED TABLE 2>' )

Schedule this transformation flow according to how fresh you need the timestamp. A typical balance is hourly — fine-grained enough for most BI needs but light on compute. (If you need real-time, use the import chains that run on every update; see Pattern B below.)

Pattern B — Import using a task chain and table persistence

If you use a task chain to import or persist tables, attach a final transformation step that writes the current timestamp / last-change value to 1TL_Last_Delta. For persisted tables you can also read the “<TABLE>_Delta” tables using a transformation flow to determine last modification time. Careful this may lead to false information incase you persist your data without checking if new data is available.

 

4) Combine tracked data into a single SQL view your model can consume

You may have to join or union several tables or tracked objects (for a model that depends on multiple tables). Example view:

SELECT
  t."VIEW_NAME",
  t."LAST_REFRESH"
FROM "<SPACE_NAME>"."TRACK_REFRESH" t
WHERE t."VIEW_NAME" IN ('<TRACKED_TABLE_1>', '<TRACKED_TABLE_2>', '<TRACKED_TABLE_3>')
UNION ALL
-- optional: an aggregated row (MAX of two tracked tables)
SELECT
  'MAX_<TRACKED_TABLE_1>_<TRACKED_TABLE_2>' AS "VIEW_NAME",
  MAX(t."LAST_REFRESH") AS "LAST_REFRESH"
FROM "<SPACE_NAME>"."TRACK_REFRESH" t
WHERE t."VIEW_NAME" IN ('<TRACKED_TABLE_1>', '<TRACKED_TABLE_2>')

 

 

5) Expose to SAP Analytics Cloud

Option A — Single analytic model with a View_Name variable (recommended)

  • Create a Datasphere Analytic Model that exposes the view created in step 4 and add a filter variable View_Name.
  • In the SAC story, set the variable to the name of the table your story is dependent on. Then add dynamic text that references the Last_Refresh value.

Pros: fewer models to maintain, single point of truth.
Cons: depends on how well story variables persist and on your story variable settings for bookmarks; if your story must clear variables on load, you may use the pattern below.

Option B — One analytic model per story / analytic model

If you cannot rely on story-level variables (for example if your stories use “Clear Variables and Use Server-Defined Values” or bookmarks that clear variables), create a small analytic model per story or analytic model that already filters to the “VIEW_NAME”-value that story needs.

Pros: deterministic for each story/leading table and avoids variable state issues or user from changing the variable.
Cons: model overhead with poor maintainability.

Option C — Integration in existing analytic model

If you cannot rely on story-level variables (for example if your stories use “Clear Variables and Use Server-Defined Values” or bookmarks that clear variables), you can also integrate the timestamps in the existing analytical model. this may be more difficult in complex analytic models and produces excess data and is poor to maintain!

 

6) Display in SAC story

Once the LAST_REFRESH is available as a dimension in your SAC Story you can add a text box to the story and Insert → Dynamic Text → Dimension → choose <ANALYICAL_MODEL> → choose “Last Refresh”. Also make sure to configure the filter accordingly to step 5.

I recommend using "Last Updated" for Pattern A and "Data Current as of" for Pattern B from step 3.

 

References

  • Add Dynamic Text to a Story  SAP Help Portal
  • Set Story Variables SAP Help Portal
  • OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES System View (HANA Cloud SQL reference) SAP Help Portal
  • Community thread discussing “get latest datasource update/refresh” SAP Community
  • SAP Note 2706430 - How to get latest datasource update/refresh data date/time in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • Improvement Request 219791 - Dynamic text for datasource last refresh date and time

entry.title: Session 1 Recap & Highlight - SAP BDC The Future of Intelligent Data Architectures 🚀
entry.content:
Why SAP Invested in BDC 💡

The journey started with SAP’s recognition of a growing "context gap" in enterprise data—which emerges when organizations must stitch together SAP and non-SAP data across disparate platforms (think Databricks, Snowflake, Microsoft Fabric). Without business context, analytics and AI initiatives often struggle to deliver real value. BDC was built to close this gap by harmonizing and managing all enterprise data—structured, semi-structured, SAP, and non-SAP—in a unified, semantically enriched way.

 

What Sets BDC Apart? 🎯

  • Automation First: BDC flips the script on traditional data management, automating data curation and harmonization. Instead of endless upfront effort, customers get ready-to-consume, semantically rich data products—saving time and reducing what SAP calls the “hidden data tax”.
  • Data Product Model: SAP identifies “primary data products” (like finance, supply chain, HR) and brings them directly from SAP applications into BDC, curated and cataloged for instant use. The goal is to reach 500 data products by year-end—covering virtually every major enterprise domain.
  • AI-Ready Fabric: BDC’s lakehouse architecture and built-in “business fabric” layer empower businesses to use advanced analytics, natural language queries, and AI seamlessly. Dual integration and knowledge graph support mean both applications and users can access harmonized, context-rich insights.

 

Interoperability & Ecosystem 🌐

  • BDC Connect: This technology helps integrate BDC with non-SAP systems like Databricks, enabling zero-copy data sharing and harmonized catalogs—perfect for hybrid and multicloud enterprises.
  • Marketplace Vision: SAP is launching a data products marketplace, encouraging partners and customers to publish, consume, and innovate with SAP and non-SAP data. The upcoming announcement at SAP Connect will explain how the ecosystem and intelligent apps can grow—most delivered by partners, not just SAP.

 

Data Democratization: Empowering Every Employee 👥

Pinar described SAP’s internal rollout—“customer zero”—where business users, not just IT, access BDC’s data products and build dashboards in hours. This isn’t just technology; SAP orchestrates enablement cohorts, training citizen analysts to maximize value and foster data-driven decision making at every level.

  • Reusable Data Products: Designed for broad, multi-use case consumption, not one-off analytics. Both IT and business users (citizen analysts) can build, extend, and share data-driven solutions thanks to low-code/no-code tooling.
  • Enablement & Governance: SAP couples technology with strong governance and enablement programs—using Collibra for cataloging, trust-building, and making metadata as easy to navigate as grocery shopping.

 

 

🌍Whether you’re an enterprise architect, citizen analyst, or just curious about the future of business intelligence—SAP Business Data Cloud delivers a new foundation for turning data into real business outcomes, faster and smarter than ever before.

entry.title: Unlocking a Cleaner and Greener Energy Future with AI
entry.content:
The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) mandate rapid clean energy adoption to combat climate change. However, many utilities still face hurdles integrating renewables such as solar, wind, and hydropower into increasingly intelligent, distributed grids. Digital transformation, powered by AI, can enable accurate forecasting, predictive analytics, and IoT-driven self-healing grids, unlocking a sustainable future at scale.

Gartner projects that by 2027, over 50% of enterprise AI models will be industry-specific, up from about 1% in 2023. For utilities, this shift toward domain-tuned AI accelerates adoption in forecasting, asset performance, and customer operations. IDC’s Utilities predictions and Forrester’s Generative AI outlook similarly point to a pivot from pilot to production, with measured value in core operational use cases

AI Use Cases and SAP Utilities Solutions:

  • Advanced Renewable Forecasting: AI brings together historical generation, weather, and grid conditions to predict renewable output, enhance grid stability, and optimize dispatch. SAP enablers: SAP Energy Data Management (EDM), SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), SAP Datasphere for data fabric, and SAP S/4HANA Utilities for integration.
  • Intelligent Demand-Side Management: AI dynamically adjusts loads across sectors - smart appliances, EVs, industrial processes balancing supply and reducing peaks. SAP enablers: SAP Cloud for Utilities, SAP BRIM and SAP Subscription Billing for innovative tariffs, and SAC for optimization.
  • Proactive Predictive Maintenance: AI-driven anomaly detection improves asset reliability and avoids costly outages. SAP enablers: SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), SAP Asset Intelligence Network (AIN), SAP Field Service Management (FSM), and SAP S/4HANA Asset Management.

What are the opportunities of converging AI and SAP Solutions?

  • Reliability & Predictive Maintenance at Scale
    AI models fuse SCADA, asset history, and condition data to detect anomalies early, optimize spares, and move from time-based to condition-based maintenance - cutting SAIDI/SAIFI and truck rolls.

SAP enablers: SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), SAP Field Service Management (FSM), SAP S/4HANA Asset Management, SAP Asset Intelligence Network (AIN), and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for predictive insights.

  • DER Orchestration, Flexibility & Market Settlement
    Forecasting and dispatching behind-the-meter solar, storage, EVs, and microgrids; forming virtual power plants (VPPs)  and optimizing participation in flexibility/ancillary markets.

SAP enablers: SAP Energy Data Management (EDM) for metering and settlement, SAP Billing and Revenue Innovation Management (BRIM) and SAP Subscription Billing for new tariffs and flexibility services, SAP S/4HANA Utilities for end-to-end customer-to-cash, and SAP Analytics Cloud for forecast optimization.

  • Customer & Prosumer Experience (CX) and Personalized Energy Services
    Hyper-personalized advisory, usage insights, TOU nudges, EV-smart-charging offers, and prosumer engagement that drive satisfaction and reduce churn.

SAP enablers: SAP S/4HANA Utilities, SAP BRIM for complex pricing/bundles, SAP Subscription Billing, SAP Customer Data Platform (CDP), SAP Service Cloud, and SAP Marketing Cloud for tailored engagement.

  • Sustainability, Emissions & “Green AI” Operations
    AI to optimize dispatch, reduce losses, and cut emissions; automated Scope 1–3 tracking and audit-ready reporting; and energy-efficient AI practices to minimize compute footprints.

SAP enablers: SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) for KPI governance, SAP Product Footprint Management (PFM) for footprint calculations, SAP Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS) for operational compliance, and SAP Signavio for process redesign.

  • Workforce Productivity, Safety & Knowledge Capture
    AI copilots for planners/dispatchers; mobile assistants for field technicians (procedures, PPE checks, hazards); automated close-outs and claims; and computer vision for safety observance.

SAP enablers: SAP Field Service Management (FSM) (mobile work), SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) (procedures & failure modes), SAP EHS (permits/safety), SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Enable Now for just-in-time guidance.

  • Revenue Innovation & Margin Protection
    AI-informed margin management (hedging, loss reduction), prosumer/VPP monetization, dynamic pricing, flexibility services, and performance-based programs.

SAP enablers: SAP BRIM, SAP Subscription Billing, SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM), SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Datasphere (data fabric for scenario modeling).

Let's look at the challenges and practical mitigations

  • Data Foundations, Quality & Interoperability: Model performance hinges on clean, timely, connected data across OT (SCADA, AMI, APM) and IT (billing, CRM).

Mitigations with SAP: Establish a utility data fabric with SAP Datasphere; unify meter/market data via SAP EDM; standardize models in SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP); use SAP Integration Suite for OT/IT connectors; govern with SAP Master Data Governance (MDG).

  • AI Risk, Governance & Model Compliance (AI TRiSM/Responsible AI): Bias, drift, explainability, safety, and regulatory scrutiny (especially for GenAI and automated decisioning).

Mitigations with SAP: Use SAP BTP with SAP AI Core and AI Launchpad for lifecycle control; log lineage and approvals; embed human-in-the-loop; instrument KPIs in SAC; codify policies in Signavio.

  • Cybersecurity & Critical Infrastructure Protection: Expanded attack surface across DERs, edge devices, mobile crews, and market interfaces; GenAI introduces new vectors (prompt injection, data leakage).

Mitigations with SAP: Apply least-privilege and policy-based access on SAP BTP; integrate security analytics; segment OT/IT interfaces; harden APIs with SAP Integration Suite; capture end-to-end audit trails.

  • Compute, Energy Footprint & “Green AI”: Training/serving advanced models can inflate energy use, potentially conflicting with utility decarbonization goals.

Mitigations with SAP: Favor smaller, domain-tuned models hosted efficiently on SAP BTP; leverage inference optimization, demand-response scheduling of batch jobs, and carbon-aware routing; track emissions in SAP Sustainability Control Tower and Product Footprint Management.

  • Talent, Change & Operating Model: AI value stalls without product-centric teams, MLOps, and business ownership of outcomes.

Mitigations with SAP: Establish an AI value office; use SAP Signavio for process redesign; adopt MLOps on BTP/AI Launchpad; embed copilot-assisted work in SAP FSM and SAP S/4HANA.

  • Regulatory, Market & Ethical Constraints: Rate design, model explainability, and consumer data use are under tightening scrutiny.

Mitigations with SAP: Keep explainability artifacts for decisions (SAC narratives, model cards in AI Launchpad); enforce privacy-by-design with SAP CDP and consent management; maintain audit trails across EDM/BRIM/market processes.

Conclusion: 

AI is the cornerstone for clean energy transformation. By leveraging SAP’s intelligent utilities solutions and TCS’s innovation, utilities can boost efficiency, integrate renewables, and drive decarbonization. The path to a greener future lies in combining advanced technology with strategic energy management and robust governance. For CXOs, this means making informed, data-driven decisions, ensuring regulatory compliance, and creating sustainable value for customers and shareholders alike. Those who act decisively today will not only navigate the energy transition successfully but also set the benchmark for resilient, future-ready utilities.

entry.title: Basic Tips for Beginners in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with BW Live
entry.content:
Beginner Tips for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with BW Live Connection

While working in SAC, I faced some common challenges. Here are the problems and how I solved them:

1. Story and Page Filters with BW Live Data

    • Problem: I was not sure whether SAC filters process locally or in BW.
    • Solution: Filters always trigger BW to recalculate and send back results. Only cosmetic changes (sort, format, hide columns) happen in SAC.

2. Scripting – Dynamic Input Handling

    • Problem: When using input fields, numbers were treated as text and gave wrong results in calculations.
    • Solution: Convert string to number:
    • var numberValue = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(InputField_1.getValue());

3. Debugging Data in a Widget

    • Problem: I could not see what exactly my table widget was holding in the backend.
    • Solution: Use ResultSet in script:

              var resultset = Table_1.getDataSource().getResultSet();

              console.log(resultset);

This showed me all members and values in console.

4. Performance Issue with Dimensions

    • Problem: My story was very slow though I used only few attributes in the widget.
    • Solution: Reduced unnecessary attributes in the model → story became faster.

✅These are small but practical solutions that helped me when starting SAC development. I hope this helps other beginners too.

It’s imperative that in today’s economy, data is more than just numbers—it’s the foundation of innovation, strategy, and growth backed by AI. SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a structured, four-phase approach that helps enterprises transform raw data into actionable insights while building a strong data-driven culture. 

The Four Phases of SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology 

1. Scoping & Baseline Analysis: In this phase you can set the foundation by: 

  • Defining the scope of investigation across business processes, organizational units, and data domains. 
  • Assessing current data architecture and capabilities. 
  • Identifying gaps, pain points, and opportunities for improvement. 

Benefit of this phase is that your business will have a clear baseline architecture, capability assessment, and prioritized opportunities.

With this phase the target solution architecture is validated through capability mapping and pilots. 

 4. Data Governance & Roadmaps: this final phase ensures long-term sustainability: 

  • Conduct a maturity assessment for data governance and organizational roles. 
  • Define roles such as Chief Data Officer, Data Steward, and Governance Manager. 
  • Build a roadmap with clear clusters (e.g., implementation, operations, security). 

The key benefit of this phase is to define Data governance framework, organizational structure, and a roadmap for execution. 

What makes SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology stand out is that it’s not just about technology—it’s about data, people and processes. By integrating governance, roles, and organizational change management, it ensures that data initiatives aren’t just implemented but also adopted across the enterprise. For organizations aiming to thrive in a data-driven economy, SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology provides more than a roadmap—it delivers a proven framework for turning data into business value and give it purpose. By combining architecture best practices with governance and cultural adoption, it helps enterprises evolve from simply managing data to truly innovating with it.

entry.title: Your Spreadsheet on Steroids: 6 Powerful New Features for the SAC Excel Add-in
entry.content:
For data analysts and planners, the debate between the flexibility of Microsoft Excel and the governed power of enterprise platforms like SAP Analytics Cloud is a familiar one. Excel offers unparalleled freedom for ad-hoc analysis, while SAC provides a single source of truth, robust security, and collaborative scale. This often creates a clunky workflow, forcing users to manually rebuild analyses as they move between environments.
Recent updates to the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) add-in for Microsoft Excel are fundamentally changing this dynamic, bridging the gap between these two worlds in powerful and surprising ways. This post highlights four of the most impactful new features that are transforming the add-in from a simple data connector into an indispensable tool for serious analysis and planning.
1. From Polished Story to Powerful Spreadsheet in a Single Click
A significant update in the Q3 / 2025.17 release introduces the ability to transfer a table directly from an SAP Analytics Cloud story into Excel. This isn't just a static copy-paste of values; the transferred table is fully functional within the add-in. It retains the same data source, navigation state (including all dimensions, measures, rows, and columns), filters, and variables that were configured in the story.
This creates an immediate, frictionless pivot from a high-level presentation in a Story to a granular, what-if analysis in Excel. Analysts can now investigate an anomaly they spot in a dashboard without losing a moment of momentum or context rebuilding the query.
Note: You need to migrate your table to the New table experience available from 2025 QRC3 release. The option to open the story in a Excel Add-in needs to be enabled in Table properties in the Builder Panel.

This enables Open in Excel Add-in option in Table.

 Eureka, Story opens in Excel with structure and calculations migrated.

 

2. Your Data Now Has a Voice: In-Cell Conversations Arrive
The 2025.15 release brings collaboration directly to your data cells with the introduction of data point comments. Users can now view and create comments on specific data cells within their Excel tables. Critically, these comments are fully synchronized with SAP Analytics Cloud, meaning a comment added in Excel is immediately visible in the web application, and vice versa.
To make this even more powerful, the SAP.GETDATACOMMENT formula (introduced in version 2025.17) allows you to retrieve these comments programmatically. If multiple comments exist for a data point, the formula returns the last comment of the thread. This development marks a shift from static reporting to true collaborative analysis. The addition of the SAP.GETDATACOMMENT formula elevates these comments from simple annotations to query able metadata. This unlocks the ability to build exception reports, dashboards, or even KPIs based on the presence and content of commentary, creating a powerful new layer of qualitative analysis.
 
Enable data point comments from the Table Option in Designer Panel

This will enable a comment widget to add comments

The comments are in sync and can be viewed in web stories also and vice versa.

3. Enterprise-Grade Guardrails for Your Planning Spreadsheets

 

For organizations using the add-in for financial planning, the 2025.17 release delivers a crucial governance enhancement. Data Access Controls (DCS) and Validation Rules that are defined in the central SAP Analytics Cloud model are now automatically applied and visualized directly within the Excel add-in.
This is a critical update because it de-risks the use of Excel for enterprise planning. It allows finance teams to leverage the full flexibility of their preferred tool while ensuring that every input automatically inherits the security, data integrity rules, and governance defined in the central SAC model. The "Wild West" spreadsheet is officially tamed.
 
4. A Faster, More Intuitive Way to Build Your Analysis
A pair of recent user experience enhancements have combined to make the process of building and modifying analyses significantly faster and more intuitive. First, version 2025.13 introduced a resizable builder panel that features a permanent pane listing all available dimensions and measures. This allows for easy browsing and searching of the data source objects.
Building on that foundation, version 2025.19 added drag-and-drop functionality. Users can now simply drag objects from the permanent list and drop them into the desired pane (e.g., rows or columns) to build out their table. These  updates work together to reduce clicks and streamline the entire analysis design process, letting users get to insights more quickly.
 

5. Make your sheets colorful

Now you can add styling and thresholds to your Excel tables. This helps applying corporate colors or creating a more visual appealing layouts.

You can use a list of SAC predefined cell styles or create custom cell styles by duplicating and existing cell styles.

You can choose the styling as well as the area of the table layout where it should be applied.

6. Create Calculated Measure ( Episode 1 : Restricted Measure support)

The long awaited feature of the ability to create calculated measures for your business calculation is now available also in Excel. As a first feature set, only restricted measures are supported. The steps are very similar to how we define calculations in web story. Currently only value based restrictions are supported ( both dimension and attributes). No support for dynamic restrictions for date dimensions like Current Period, prior Period etc. readily available in web stories. Never the less its a good start and I wish to see the remaining features soon. Both restricted accounts and restricted measures are supported.

Already defined Calculations can also be edited if required.

 

Conclusion: A Final Thought
The SAP Analytics Cloud add-in for Excel is rapidly evolving. It's moving beyond its origins as a simple data connector to become a fully-featured, collaborative, and secure extension of the core platform. By bringing enterprise governance and modern collaboration features into the familiar grid of a spreadsheet, it offers a powerful new paradigm for analysis and planning.
With these new capabilities fusing the best of Excel and the cloud, what established workflow are you now ready to rethink?
 
Thanks for reading. I hope you enjoyed the blog.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - From Provisioning to Intelligent Applications
entry.content:
Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud

In this blog, we will try to go over the Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and then the Components and Building Blocks of SAP BDC.

SAP BDC is a fully managed software-as-a-service (SaaS) offering from SAP designed to address this need of managing vast volumes of data originating from diverse systems. It consolidates and governs all SAP data while seamlessly integrating third-party sources, delivering contextualized, trusted data to business leaders for more impactful decision-making. By harmonizing mission-critical data into a unified semantic layer, the platform eliminates the overhead of data extraction and replication.  Supporting a wide range of use cases across industries and business functions, SAP BDC ensures that data is consistently accessible, secure, and ready for advanced analytics.

Key Aspects of SAP Business Data Cloud

  • Intelligent Applications: AI-driven apps that leverage your data and business context to automate processes, adapt dynamically, and drive transformative outcomes in real time.
  • Data Products: Prebuilt, customizable, and governed data assets that come enriched with business semantics, documentation, and APIs—accelerating deployment across a wide range of use cases.
  • Business Data Fabric: A comprehensive data and analytics foundation that integrates SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, modernized SAP Business Warehouse, data engineering capabilities, and AI/ML innovations through SAP Databricks.
  • AI-Enriched Decision Making: Enterprise-grade tools that deliver responsible, context-aware AI for reporting and analytics —empowering smarter, faster decisions.

Components of SAP Business Data Cloud

Source Systems:  SAP BDC connects seamlessly to various source systems—such as SAP S/4HANA—to identify and extract key business data entities. These include tables, views, and other structures that contain mission-critical data across domains like HR, finance, supply chain. By integrating with these systems, SAP BDC ensures that foundational business data is readily available for analytics, governance, and intelligent application development.

Foundational Services in SAP Business Data Cloud: Within SAP BDC, data extracted from source systems flows into the Foundation Services layer. This foundational component is responsible for ingesting, integrating, cleansing, and harmonizing both structured and unstructured data. It ensures that the data is properly aligned and enriched as part of SAP-managed Data Products, forming the backbone of trusted, analytics-ready information across the SAP BDC landscape.

SAP Datasphere: SAP Datasphere serves as the modeling and governance layer atop the BDC Semantic Layer. It provides a robust set of tools for designing analytical data models, defining business logic, managing data lineage, enforcing governance and security. In addition to its core modeling capabilities, SAP Datasphere supports machine learning and AI extensions, making it a foundational component for advanced analytics and intelligent decision-making. Datasphere acts as the data engine behind SAP Analytics Cloud, feeding it with both prebuilt and custom insights for reporting and visualization. It also enables customers to create custom data products using the SAP Datasphere Object Store, which supports zero-copy data access via the Delta Sharing Protocol - ensuring efficient, secure, and scalable data sharing across the enterprise.

SAP Databricks: SAP Databricks is a specialized integration of the Databricks platform embedded directly within SAP BDC. It combines industry-leading capabilities in AI, machine learning, data science, and data engineering with semantically rich, business-ready data from SAP applications. This component significantly enhances analytics by enabling generative AI scenarios—without the need for complex data pipelines. Through zero-copy Delta Sharing, SAP Databricks connects directly to SAP Data Products, allowing seamless access and enrichment of data without replication. By bridging enterprise-grade SAP data with the flexibility of Databricks, organizations can accelerate innovation, streamline operations, and unlock deeper insights across their business landscape.

SAP Analytics Cloud: SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) empowers business analytics by directly consuming integrated data from the SAP Datasphere component within BDC. It supports rich visualization, reporting, and AI-driven analytics across the enterprise—all within a unified, cloud-based SaaS environment. By leveraging semantically aligned data from Datasphere, SAC enables organizations to generate actionable insights, build dynamic dashboards, and drive informed decision-making at scale.

SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA Integration: To support legacy compatibility, SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA objects can be technically onboarded into SAP BDC. This integration enables organizations to migrate data and maintain hybrid use cases—bridging traditional data warehousing with modern cloud-based analytics—until the official end-of-support timeline for BW systems. By incorporating BW artifacts into BDC, businesses can preserve existing investments while gradually transitioning to a unified, governed, and AI-ready data landscape.

Building Blocks of SAP Business Data Cloud

Provisioning an SAP Business Data Cloud Tenant

An SAP BDC tenant is provisioned via the SAP for Me portal using a guided, self-service workflow. This process enables organizations to activate and configure the components of SAP Business Data Cloud according to their commercial entitlements. The provisioning journey begins with the BDC Core Component or Cockpit, which serves as the central management interface for the entire SAP BDC landscape. 

Once the BDC cockpit is provisioned, the next step is to provision (from SAP for Me) the core capabilities and applications, including: SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks.

After these systems are successfully provisioned through SAP for Me, users can  begin creating Formations—structured configurations that define how data products and applications are orchestrated across the landscape.

Formation in SAP Business Data Cloud

A Formation in SAP Business Data Cloud is a logical grouping of SAP systems and related components designed to support specific business scenarios or integration use cases. Formations simplify connectivity and provide a unified view of all systems, making it easier to manage integrations, extensions, and orchestrate data across the SAP BDC landscape.  Formations are created by selecting the required SAP systems—these must first be provisioned via the SAP for Me portal. Once provisioned, they appear in the Systems tab of the portal and can be included in one or more formations. Each formation can consist of multiple systems such as SAP BDC Core, SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP BW, SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks. These systems are synchronized within the formation to enable streamlined operations and cohesive business processes. Multiple formations can be created to support extended or complex business scenarios.

Benefits of Using Formations

  • Simplified Integration: Centralizes the grouping and management of systems required for a business scenario.
  • Scalability and Flexibility: Easily add or remove systems as organizational needs evolve.
  • Governance and Control: Enables centralized configuration and oversight, improving compliance and reducing maintenance overhead.

SAP Data Products in Business Data Cloud 

An SAP Data Product is a curated and refined dataset derived from data ingested from SAP solutions. It encompasses a Business Data Set that includes master data, transactional records, analytics datasets, and configuration data—all semantically aligned to ensure consistency and usability.

These datasets are enriched with meaningful metadata and documentation, making them easily consumable and understandable. Within the SAP BDC, Data Products serve as the core building blocks for Intelligent Applications, enabling advanced analytics and decision-making.  SAP delivers and manages these Data Products as part of its SaaS offering, maintaining full lifecycle ownership. However, customers can customize them to suit specific business needs. Each Data Product includes all necessary artifacts—such as CDS views, connectors, flows, jobs, and lifecycle management tools—required to support its associated use cases within SAP BDC. They are easily discoverable through the SAP BDC product catalog. These products are designed by line-of-business experts to help organizations maximize the value of their data. Types of Data Products

  • Primary Data Products: Directly sourced from applications, representing original data from systems like SAP S/4HANA. They are not derived from other data products.
  • Derived Data Products: Built by SAP using existing datasets or APIs. This offer added value by combining or transforming data from multiple sources.

Custom or Customer Managed Data Products : SAP BDC also supports custom data products, which can be curated within SAP Datasphere. These leverage the Datasphere Object Store and Delta Sharing Protocol, enabling zero-copy data access for efficient and secure data sharing.

Intelligent Applications in SAP Business Data Cloud

Intelligent Applications are AI-driven, visualization-centric solutions designed to address specific business scenarios. Unlike general-purpose analytics tools, these applications are built with SAP-managed analytical assets and functionalities that deliver value through process, domain, or analytical intelligence. They typically include data products, semantic models, and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) stories. These applications foster collaboration between analytics and data science teams by providing ready-made dashboards enriched with AI-generated insights. Their embedded business logic and contextual data models eliminate the need for organizations to build complex analytical frameworks from scratch—saving time and resources. The core structure of Intelligent Applications includes:

  • SAC Stories: Serve as the front-end interface, offering rich visualizations tailored to specific analytics use cases.
  • SAP Datasphere Models and Views: Includes the backend logic and data orchestration.
  • Semantic Models and Story Templates: Combined to deliver reusable, customizable dashboards.

These applications are cataloged within the SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC), making them easy to discover, deploy, and extend.

Installation and Customization

To explore and install Intelligent Applications:

  1. Log in to the SAP BDC Cockpit. Browse the available applications and their documentation.
  2. Upon installation, a suite of artifacts is deployed across SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud, including Data Products, Replication Flows, Tables and Views, Analytic Models, Roles and Dashboards.

 Customization Guidelines

  • SAP-managed applications and their dependencies are read-only, but users can copy and adapt components.
  • SAC Stories can be duplicated and tailored to meet specific business needs.
  • For advanced scenarios, users may replicate and modify the underlying analytic models ( within SAP Datasphere).
  • Changes to models will affect both the original and copied stories, so version control and impact analysis are recommended.

Key Differentiation between Business Content and Intelligent Applications

  • Business Content provides a set of pre-built models and other artifacts, but customers manage the implementation, configuration and maintenance of these solutions.
  • Intelligent Applications are fully managed and curated by SAP and delivered as software-as-a-service designed to cater specific business use cases or scenarios.

Hope this helps you understand the basics and get started on SAP Business Data Cloud.

entry.title: Planning & Analytics (P&A) is an essential part of SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC)
