entry.title: SAML SSO configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
entry.content:
How to Configure SAML on SAP Analytics Cloud Tenant Using IAS as a Custom IDP

With SAML 2.0 Single Sign-On (SSO), you can simplify authentication for your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) users while improving security and reducing password fatigue. By integrating SAC with SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) (or any other identity provider) as a custom Identity Provider (IdP), you gain centralized control over user access and streamline the login experience.

In this guide, we’ll walk through the process of setting up SAML-based SSO step-by-step — from prerequisites to verification — ensuring a smooth configuration process for administrators.

What You’ll Learn

This guide is divided into three main sections:

  1. Prerequisites – Everything you need to prepare before starting the configuration.

  2. Step-by-Step Configuration – Detailed steps to set up SAML SSO between SAC and IAS.

  3. Verification and Go-Live – How to verify and finalize your configuration.

  4. Troubleshooting – Common issues, tips, and SAP Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs) to help you quickly resolve errors during or after setup.

By the end, you’ll have a fully functional SAML-based authentication setup, ready for production.

 

Configuring SAML SSO with IAS

Follow these steps carefully to configure SAML authentication for your SAC tenant.

Before you begin, make sure the following requirements are met. Prerequisites for SAC configuration:

  1. You must have an IdP that supports SAML 2.0 protocol.
  2. You must be able to configure your IdP.
  3. You must be assigned to the System Owner role in SAP Analytics Cloud. For more information, see Standard Application Roles.
  4. SAP Analytics Cloud can be hosted either on SAP data centers or on non-SAP data centers. Determine which environment SAP Analytics Cloud is hosted in by inspecting your SAP Analytics Cloud URL:
    • A single-digit number, for example us1 or jp1, indicates an SAP data center.
    • A two-digit number, for example eu10 or us30, indicates a non-SAP data center.
  5. If your users are connecting from Apple devices using the SAP Analytics Cloud mobile app, the certificate used by your IdP must be compatible with Apple's App Transport Security (ATS) feature.

Follow help page to enable SAML SSO : Enable a Custom SAML Identity Provider (Legacy Custom IdP)

Configuration steps:

1. Login to SAP Analytics Cloud tenant as System Owner with Default IDP.

2. Navigate to “System -> Administration”.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3. From “Administration” tab switch to “Security” page, click on Edit button on the right corner and switch to SAML Single Sign-on SSO from SAP Cloud Identity (default).

4. Download metadata file mentioned under Step 1 “Download Service Provider metadata” in SAC and save it to your local machine.

5. Upload the SAP Analytics Cloud metadata file to your SAML IdP.

To complete this step, you will need to login to Cloud Identity Provisioning Services (IAS) and navigate to the following path “Applications & Resources -> Application -> Select your IAS application -> SAML 2.0 Configuration”. Under “Define from Metadata” section click on Browse and upload the metadata file which was downloaded from SAC in step 3 above.

6.  Map your SAML IdP user attributes and roles. 

After SAC metadata has been uploaded into IAS, navigate to “Applications & Resources -> Application -> Select your IAS application -> Attributes”  and configure SAML mapping as it is defined in step 7 in help page  Enable a Custom SAML Identity Provider.

Important! - For SAML attributes to be recognized it is also important that the “Groups” attribute contains the value of “sac''

7. In IAS, navigate to Tenant Settings tab under ''Application & Resources.''

Under Single Sign-on section, click on SAML 2.0 Configuration tab, and download metadata file from there.

Switch back to SAC tenant and continue Step 2 “Upload Identity Provider metadata”, upload the metadata file there.

8. Now we need to define User Attribute in Step 3 “Choose a user attribute to map to your identity provider” in SAC. It should map to User ID, Email, or a custom attribute. You can view your SAP Analytics Cloud user attributes in Security Users.

The attribute will be used to map users from your Custom IDP (in this case IAS)  to SAP Analytics Cloud. The user attribute you select must match the NameID (Subject Name Identifier) used in your custom SAML assertion.

In IAS tenant navigate to “Applications & Resources -> Application -> Select your IAS application -> Subject Name Identifier” and select same User Attribute for  “Select a basic attribute”, which was defined in SAP Analytics Cloud.

9. In Step 4, enter <Your Unique Identifier>. This value must identify the SAP Analytics Cloud system owner. The Login Credential provided here will be automatically set for your user.

Which means if attribute is set to email in step 3, then System Owner’s email should be defined in step 4 as per screenshot below.

10. After above steps have been completed, click on “Verify Account”. You can copy the URL by selecting  (Copy).

Please Note that: You must use a private session (Incognito) to log onto the URL; for example, Guest mode in Chrome. This ensures that when you log on to the dialog and select SAP Analytics Cloud, you are prompted to log in and do not reuse an existing browser session.

11. In the Verify Your Account dialog, select Check Verification. If the verification was successful, a green border should appear around the Login Credential box.

12. After verification was successful, click on save and conversion to SAML SSO should be completed.

By following all these steps, we have successfully configured SAML SSO on SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.

 

What is Identity Provider Administration Tool? 

The Identity Provider Administration tool allows system owners to manage the custom identity provider configured with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). Through the tool, the system owner can choose to upload new metadata for the current custom identity provider or revert to using the default identity provider.

You can read more about this tool here: Access the Identity Provider Administration Tool

How to access/use Identity Provider Administration Tool?

In the following, we’ll use Identity Provider Administration tool can be used to update metadata from custom IDP and how to revert SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) tenant back to default IDP.

Pre-requisites:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) must already be configured to use a custom identity provider.
  • You must be the system owner.

Procedure

  1. Log in with an S-user that has the same email address as the system owner of your system. If you don't yet have such an S-user, you can click the “Register” button and create a S-user. If you create a new S-user, you'll receive an email with an activation link that will let you set your password.

  2. Access the Identity Provider Administration tool using the following URL pattern:

    https://console.<data center>.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

    For example, if your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) system is on eu10, then the URL is:

    https://console.eu10.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

    If your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) system is on cn1, then the URL is:

    https://console.cn1.sapanalyticscloud.cn/idp-admin/

    If your tenant is on EUDP:

    https://console-eudp.eu1.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

    https://console-eudp.eu2.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

  3. Once you're logged in, you'll see a list of SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)systems for which you are the system owner.

  4. Select the system you want to work on by clicking on its row.

Once you're in the settings page for your system, you can see information about your current custom identity provider. If you need to reacquire your system's metadata, you can click the “Service Provider Metadata Download”. 

  1. If you don't want to manage your custom identity provider through Identity Provider Administration, you can disconnect your system by clicking “Disconnect IdP Admin from your system”.

  2. To proceed with either reverting to the default identity provider or updating the current custom identity provider, select the corresponding radio button and then click “Step 2”.
  3. (Optional) Revert to the default identity provider.

  4. Choose this option if you're having problems logging in with your custom identity provider and would like to revert to the default identity provider. Once the reversion has finished, you can exit the Identity Provider Administration tool and log in to your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) to reconfigure your custom identity provider.

  5. Select the “Revert to default IdP” radio button to revert to the default IdP. 
    • Select “Yes” in the confirmation dialog to revert your authentication method back to the default IdP.   
    • Click “Step 3” to proceed to the validation step.   

       
  6. To re-upload the metadata file, use “Update IdP Metadata” button.
  7. On step 2, when prompted, browse for new metadata file and re-upload it.

Relevant KBA:

  • 2908073 - How to use the IdP Admin Tool to make changes to IdP Configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud when no access is available to the tenant 
  • 2975954 - Implement multiple Identity Providers (IdP) in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

Troubleshooting

If there is any issue/error that comes up when trying to login or when configuring SAML/SSO within SAC, please make sure following is configured correctly.

  • Correct Metadata is uploaded within SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) from custom IDP
  • Certificate is not expired within Metadata.
  • Correct “NameID” is passed from Custom IDP to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • If email is used as NameID, make sure the case matches between custom IDP and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • If User ID is used as NameID, make sure it’s all in Capitals
  • During configuring SAML within SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) make sure to run verifying URL within INCOGNITO Browser window.

Example: After configuring SAML within SAC Users are not able to login and are getting errors: 

To debug the above error message, please do the steps below:

  1. Collect SAML traces as per KB 2461862 - Collecting SAML traces with Chrome, Edge or Firefox
  2. Open SAML Trace file (.json) within SAML Tracer tool, using “Import” button
  3. Once opened look for calls with SAML Tags
  4. Select “POST” call with SAML Tag and make sure all the required attributes are passed and in correct format. Pay attention to “NameID” and that it’s in correct format. 
  5. In the above example trace you can see that there is no “Groups” attribute is passed and therefore User is not able to login.

Another point which can be checked is the following:

1. To ensure the NameID attributes are matching between the 2 applications you may use the following URL:

https://<system-name>.authentication.<landscape>.hana.ondemand.com/config?action=who&details=true

2. Run the URL in an incognito browser session. It should redirect to the logon page of the Custom IdP (in this case, IAS) linked to the SAC tenant. After successful logon via the IdP credentials, look for UserName and ExternalId fields.

  • ExternalId - The value that the IdP forwards towards SAC as Subject Name Identifier (Name ID)
  • UserName - The value that is actually being compared to the SAC SAML attribute. This is due to one of the HANA services caching the value of ExternalID and storing it as UserName for faster authentication.

3. If UserName is not matching the SAC SAML attribute - authentication should fail.

NameID should be changed to ensure match between the 2 applications. If userName and SAC SAML attribute is matching - authentication should be successful

 

Conclusion

Integrating SAP Analytics Cloud with SAP Identity Authentication Service using SAML SSO brings a host of benefits:

  • Centralized authentication management across systems.

  • Enhanced security through standardized protocols.

  • Improved user experience with seamless, passwordless access.

By following this step-by-step guide, you’ve successfully configured a robust and secure SAML connection between SAC and IAS. Your users can now enjoy a simplified login experience, while you maintain full control over authentication and role management.

Relevant KBAs:

  • 2487567 - Troubleshooting SAML assertions when configuring SAML SSO in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • 2922448 - SAML Attribute Mapping in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) & SAP Digital Boardroom Master KBA
  • 2908073 - How to use the IdP Admin Tool to make changes to IdP Configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud when no access is available to the tenant
  • 2879161 - How to update the SAML IdP Signing Certificate or Metadata.xml in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

entry.title: Unsupported Features with SAP Datasphere Live Connections in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Cloud folks,

I would like to share some of the information that i searched for..

I faced lot of question after implementing SAC Stories on Live connection and this article helps to them.

when working with an SAC live connection to SAP Datasphere, you experience certain product limitations in SAC

In general, any SAP Datasphere system can be connected to any SAC system via the SAP Datasphere live connection in SAC.
Live connections between SAC and SAP Datasphere can be established across tenants . When using the SAC


– Datasphere live connection, We can build SAC stories or analytical applications that, at the same time, use data from a SAP
Datasphere space, multiple SAP Datasphere spaces, multiple SAP Datasphere spaces in multiple SAP Dataspheres as well as
any additional data sources that you have connected to SAC

When using the SAC – Datasphere live connection, SAC currently has the following product limitations:

Below are the list of  features that are not supported 

Analytics : 
Custom Shapes for Geo Maps are not supported
Version based variance features are not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Version Mapping is not supported for SAP Datasphere data.
Blending is not supported.
Scheduling a Publication is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Linked Dimension is only supported for SAP Datasphere models from the same Space. It is not supported across Spaces.
R-Visualizations are not supported. Note: you can vote for this enhancement request here.
Comment Widgets are not supported
Copy Widgets between stories is not supported
Import Pages from Stories that contain Datasphere models is not supported

JustAsk : 
On-the-fly search with Datasphere models is supported.
Indexing Datasphere models in SAC JustAsk is not supported.
Open in Data Analyzer is not supported
Copy widget to Story is not supported
Stories in Classic Experience
Blending is supported for the following scenarios
SAP Datasphere data with local SAC data
SAP Datasphere data with SAP Datasphere data from the same Datasphere space.
Blending information across Datasphere spaces, or across Datasphere tenants, or blending of Datasphere data with
other Live Connections is not supported.
Using Hyperlinks with the option "Apply selected dimension as filter" enabled across Stories using SAP Datasphere Live
Connections is not supported.
SAP Datasphere Analytic models are not supported

SAP Datasphere Data Types
The following SAP Datasphere Data types are currently not supported in SAP Analytics Cloud:
Bigint
Binary
hana.binary
Large Binary
Large String


Planning
SAC Planning data can now be stored in Datasphere with seamless planning However, planning
still requires the import of data into the SAC model and is not based on the SAP Datasphere live connection 


Smart features
Smart Insights are not supported on SAP Datasphere data. .
Smart Discovery is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Smart Predict is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
SAP Digital Boardroom
Stories built on top of SAP Datasphere live data are not supported in SAP Digital Boardroom.

Regards,

Kartheek Kota

Reference:

https://me.sap.com/notes/2832606

entry.title: Optimizing SAP Analytics Cloud – Best Practices and Performance
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) offers powerful capabilities for planning, analytics, and business intelligence—all in one unified platform. But to truly unlock its potential, it's essential to follow best practices that ensure optimal performance, scalability, and maintainability. In this blog, we’ll explore some of the insights and recommendations across four key pillars of SAC:

  • Analytics & Planning Modeling: Structuring your models for flexibility, performance, and future growth.
  • Calculations: Designing efficient formulas and leveraging SAC’s calculation engine wisely.
  • Data Actions: Automating planning workflows with precision and minimal overhead.
  • Story Building: Crafting intuitive, responsive, and insightful dashboards that drive decision-making.

Performance Considerations

Performance in SAC isn’t a post-implementation concern—it must be a core priority from the very beginning of your project. Striking the right balance between rich functionality and responsive performance is essential. While functional requirements drive business value, they must be matched by a system that performs reliably and efficiently. Performance optimization touches every layer of your SAC solution: from backend data architecture and model design to story layout, user concurrency, and even device and network configurations.

Model Design

  • Model Scope: Clearly define the model’s scope, type (planning or analytics), required metrics, and data granularity based on business objectives. This clarity prevents over engineering and ensures alignment with user needs.
  • Reusability: Build modular models that can be reused across multiple stories and planning scenarios. Reusability reduces duplication, simplifies maintenance, and accelerates development cycles.
  • Lean Model Structure: Key performance drivers include the number of measures, dimensions, hierarchies, and members per dimension. Reducing unnecessary dimensions and avoiding overly complex hierarchies directly improves query performance and system responsiveness. Focus on dimensions that are essential for data collection. Attributes such as geographic area or gender can often be derived rather than modeled as standalone dimensions. Evaluate whether static dimensions can be converted into attributes, and consider splitting large models into smaller, purpose-driven ones. Simpler models are easier to maintain, faster to calculate, and more memory efficient. Avoid adding dimensions or calculations unless they deliver clear business value.
  • Understanding Model Types: From a performance perspective, Analytic Models connected to live data sources place minimal demand on SAC infrastructure, as most of the processing load is handled by the source system itself. In contrast, Analytic Models using acquired data rely on the embedded HANA database, primarily for read operations. While this does introduce some system load, it tends to be moderate and more CPU-intensive than memory-intensive. Planning Models with acquired data, however, offer richer functionality but come with higher resource requirements—impacting both CPU and memory. Their performance is heavily influenced by model design factors such as the number of exception aggregations, the complexity and volume of dimensions, and the breadth of the user’s security context during data entry operations.
  • Additional performance-critical factors include the number of concurrent users, the volume and structure of the data, and the frequency and complexity of scheduled jobs or data actions also play a significant role in determining system responsiveness and scalability.
  • Use Measure Based Model: When designing models in SAC, opting for a Measure-Based Model is highly recommended due to its significant advantages in performance, calculation flexibility, and overall modeling efficiency.
    • Enhanced Performance & Scalability: Measure-based models are optimized for faster processing and reduced complexity, especially in large-scale planning scenarios.
    • Flexible Structure: These models support both accounts and measures, with the account dimension now optional giving you greater design freedom.
    • Reusable Calculations: You can define base measure calculations that simplify logic reuse across stories and planning workflows.
    • Advanced Aggregation: Measures can be aggregated more efficiently, improving responsiveness and reducing load times.
    • Expanded Data Type Support: Measure-based models accommodate a wider range of data types, enhancing versatility.
    • Multi-Currency Planning: With base currency measures, currency conversion becomes seamless, enabling planning across multiple currencies with ease.

Dimension Design

  • Leverage Public Dimensions: Use the Public Dimension feature to manage master data independently, allowing for centralized updates and reuse across models. Avoid importing all source system tables—focus only on dimensions relevant to data entry and planning.
  • Dimension hierarchies and members: Deep hierarchies can be resource intensive. Limit the number of levels to reduce complexity and improve query performance. Keep the number of members in each dimension—including the Account dimension—lean. Import only valid members and apply filters to exclude irrelevant data.
  • Date Dimension: Use SAC’s standard date dimension with SAP-managed hierarchies (Year–Quarter–Month–Day) to minimize performance impact.

Planning Area

  • The planning area defines the specific slice of data within a model that end users can interact with—whether through stories or data actions. When users plan on a public version in a story, SAC automatically creates an implicit private version behind the scenes. This version isn’t visible to the user but introduces system overhead, especially in models with large datasets or when multiple users are editing simultaneously. To mitigate this, it’s crucial to explicitly define the planning area in the model settings and enable it within the story. Doing so significantly reduces resource consumption during public version edits. Key recommendations include:
  • Configure a Targeted Planning Area: Set a focused scope based on business needs, using data access control, data locking, or both to restrict editable data.
  • Avoid Full Dataset Scope: Limiting the planning area prevents unnecessary data loading and improves performance.
  • Use Data Access Control(DAC): Define which users can write to specific dimensions—such as company codes or profit centers—to ensure secure and relevant access.
  • Apply Data Locking: Protect actuals from being overwritten by locking them from edits.
  • Enable Dynamic Planning Area: Set “Auto-generate based on table context” as the default. This allows the planning area to adjust automatically based on filters, story context, or table layout—ensuring users only load what they need.

SAC Planning Best Practices

  • Use Unbooked Data selectively: Enable unbooked data only when necessary—typically for planning use cases. Since it triggers resource-intensive backend queries, it's best disabled for reporting scenarios to preserve performance.
  • Implement DAC: Always activate DAC on relevant dimensions to enforce row-level security. This ensures users only see and interact with data within their authorized scope, reducing system load during public version edits. DAC should be configured during the model design phase. DAC can be turned ON in the Model Dimension through the Read/Write Property or the Data Access Filter in Role by turning the Model Data Privacy ON so DAC can be combined with role-based restrictions. Use DAC primarily on planning-relevant dimensions (E.g. Cost Center, Profit Center, Region), not on all dimensions.
  • Complement with Data Locks :  While DAC governs who can read/write data, Data Locks control when data can be modified (e.g., freezing approved budgets). This combination enhances performance, especially in multi-user environments. Minimize driving dimensions when using data locking to reduce overhead.
  • Define Validation Rules: Ensure users can only edit valid combinations of dimension members. This is particularly important for models with large dimension tables and helps maintain data integrity while improving performance.
  • Limit Private versions: Excessive private versions—especially when multiple users are editing simultaneously—can strain system resources. Regularly clean up unused private versions to maintain system efficiency.
  • Manage Date Granularity: For models with day-level granularity, consider isolating them into separate models. Use cross-model copy data actions to transfer aggregated data, reducing complexity and improving performance.
  • Use Modeler option ‘Optimize Story Building Performance’ : This prevents the automatic refresh of data during story design. When importing or writing back datasets, use filters or pre-aggregation to reduce data volume

Calculations/Data Actions

  • Prioritize Model-Level Formulas: Define calculations within the modeler rather than at the story level to reduce query load and improve responsiveness.
  • Offload Complex: Logic to Data Actions Use data actions for advanced formulas and heavy computations instead of embedding them directly in stories.
  • Restrict Execution Scope: Use the MEMBERSET statement to narrow the scope of data actions. A tightly defined scope minimizes processing time and resource usage.
  • Limit Iteration Range: Keep calculation loops (IF, FOREACH) as focused as possible. Broad iteration across dimensions can degrade performance.
  • Aggregate at the Highest Logical Level: Design calculations to occur at the most aggregated node feasible to reduce data volume and complexity.
  • Avoid Copying Calculated Accounts: Copying calculated accounts or non-standard aggregations is resource intensive. Prefer copying raw fact data when possible.
  • Configure Advanced Formulas Thoughtfully: All steps in advanced formulas execute sequentially and materialize in the model. Use variable members to streamline logic and avoid unnecessary commits.
  • Minimize Query Calls: Reduce the number of DATA() and RESULTLOOKUP() statements—each call triggers a backend query.
  • Restricted Measures Over Exception Aggregations: Exception aggregations (e.g., MIN, MAX, AVERAGE across hierarchies) are computationally expensive. Use restricted measures and advanced formulas when possible.
  • Simplify Formula Structures: Avoid breaking formulas into too many sub-steps, which increases processing overhead.
  • Recompile After Model Changes:  If performance drops after model updates, re-save the advanced formula or data action to trigger recompilation and optimization.
  • Centralize Execution for Large Volumes:  Run data actions centrally via an admin user when handling large datasets. For decentralized execution, ensure scope is tightly defined.
  • Trigger Actions Judiciously:  Avoid frequent or unnecessary data action runs. Execute only when required to conserve resources.
  • Monitor Execution Time:  Use the Data Action Monitor to track duration and identify slow-running actions.
  • Use Job Monitor for Diagnostics: Regularly review run history and step-level details to pinpoint bottlenecks and optimize performance.
  • Simplify IF Statements: Reduce reliance on IF statements by using logical operators like AND or applying filters. Each IF creates a subquery, so use sparingly.
  • Leverage Predictive Planning: Use predictive features to generate accurate forecasts based on historical data, accelerating planning cycles and improving decision-making.

Backend HANA/BW considerations

HANA modelling

  • Optimize HANA Views by following guidelines for modelling and performance tuning.
  • Perform Calculations Post-Aggregation: Whenever possible, structure views to calculate after aggregation to reduce data volume and improve speed.
  • Join on Indexed Columns: Use keys or indexed columns for joins instead of calculated fields to enhance query performance.
  • Push Logic to HANA: Keep calculations and logic within HANA to leverage pushdown capabilities and minimize SAC-side processing.
  • Blend in HANA, Not SAC: Perform data linking and blending operations in HANA to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Apply Filters Early: Early filtering reduces data load and improves query execution time.
  • Hide Unused Dimensions in SAC: Remove unnecessary metadata from SAC models to streamline performance and reduce clutter.

BW modelling

  • Design Efficient Queries: Limit the number of dimensions and hide unnecessary key figures to reduce query payload and improve responsiveness.
  • Use BW Variables Over SAC Filters: BW variables are processed server-side and offer better performance than applying filters within SAC stories.
  • Define Restricted Key Figures: in BW Avoid creating restricted key figures in SAC remote models. Instead, configure them directly in BW for optimized execution.
  • Minimize Cascading Page Filters: Page-level filters that trigger cascading effects across widgets can slow down performance. Use them sparingly and strategically.
  • Enable Query Merge: Activate query merge to consolidate backend calls, reducing latency and improving load times.
  • Enable HTTP/2 Protocol: Improves data transfer efficiency between SAC and BW, especially for large datasets.
  • Increase Parallel Sessions: Configure BW data sources to support more parallel sessions, enhancing concurrency and user experience.
  • Apply BI Authorizations for Data Security: Use BW’s built-in data-level security to control access and ensure users only retrieve data relevant to their roles.

Story Building Recommendations

Story Structure & Layout

  • Use Optimized or Unified Story Experience: Adopt the latest story building interface for enhanced performance, flexibility, and design capabilities.
  • Leverage Composites as Reusable Widgets: Composites are stored as SAC artifacts and can be reused across stories. They support both canvas and responsive layouts and allow story-level features like filters and bookmarks to apply seamlessly. Benefits include faster story creation, reduced maintenance, standardized design, and support for parallel development.
  • Use Responsive Layouts: Responsive pages automatically adjust to screen size and load faster. Unified stories offer advanced responsive rule configurations for precise control.

Content Design & Performance Optimization

  • Request Only What’s Needed: Break down information into manageable layers. Use summary or landing pages with hyperlinks to detailed views.
  • Minimize Page Count and Widget Load: Reduce the number of pages and limit data-heavy widgets per page to improve load times and user experience.
  • Optimize Charts and Tables:
    • Avoid charts with more than 500 data points.
    • Limit the number of charts per page to reduce backend requests.
    • Split large tables into smaller ones with fewer KPIs or measures.
    • Limit the number of cells and descriptive columns for readability.
    • Avoid excessive formatting rules and in-cell charts/calculations.
  • Use Lightweight Visuals:  Replace large image files with lightweight SVGs to reduce rendering time.

Filtering & Data Handling:

  • Implement Filters Strategically: Apply filters at the document level rather than creating generic views. Use page filters instead of individual chart filters. Avoid loading all data and filtering afterward.
  • Limit Hierarchy Depth: in Filters Deep hierarchies can slow down performance—use only necessary levels.
  • Minimize Data Blending: Sources Keep the number of blended data sources low to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Pause Data Refresh During Design: Use the “Pause Data Refresh” option to optimize story loading while building.

Security & Access Control

  • Test With User Roles: Validate story performance using roles with end user authorizations—not just the admin role—to simulate real-world usage.
  • Apply Data Access Control (DAC): Ensure users only see data relevant to their role. For example, use filters for company code and profit center rather than displaying all dimensions.

Planning-Specific Tips

  • Use Fluid Data Entry Mode: This default mode offers better performance and interactivity. Avoid Single Data Entry mode, which is slower.
  • Enable Planning Only Where Needed: Activate planning features on tables only when required. Disable planning in the builder panel if not used.

Latest Performance Improvements

  • New Table Build Experience:  Optimized Stories – Edit Mode Enhancements.
    • Blended Tables: Initial page loading is faster.
    • Calculations: Automatically retained when tables are copied.
    • Improved Filtering & Sorting: More efficient workflows and reduced query errors.
    • Ghost Table: Instant layout preview before data loads
  • Story Design Optimization:
    • Performance recommendations in Edit Mode available for story designers in the optimized story experience.
    • Available for widget, page, and stories levels.
  • Preload pages
    • It can be enabled in edit mode under Data Refresh->Loading Optimization Settings-> Preload Pages.
    • Preloading will initialize parts of the next and previous page, so switching to these pages will now be faster.

If performance issues persist despite optimization efforts, SAC offers a suite of diagnostic tools to help pinpoint the root cause. These tools provide visibility into query execution, data action performance, and story load behavior. For detailed guidance on using these diagnostics, refer to the official SAP Help documentation or reach out to SAP Support for expert help.

entry.title: Archive SAC Change Docs into Datasphere
entry.content:
Using SAC data change documents, you can track (audit) the data changes made to any planning model. SAP Analytics Cloud logs all changes to the transaction data of that model when users publish data from private versions to public versions.

Note that a data change log has up to 2^31 (i.e., 2,147,384,648, or ~2 billion) records. When the data change log reaches its size limit, publishing data will fail, and you will see the following message:

Publish cannot be performed because the data audit table has reached the maximum number of rows.

To avoid this issue, consider periodically downloading log entries as a backup before deleting them.

This document shows a design to back up SAC audit logs into Datasphere. Using Datasphere dataflow to back up change documents from the SAC Data Export Service via a Cloud Data Integration adapter-based connection, it can back up and preserve the SAC audit log history, which is necessary for regular housekeeping in SAC due to storage capacity limits.

 

DES: data export service

CDI: cloud data integration

 

Note: In SAC seamless planning or in BDC, the SAC model definition and calculation logic remain within SAC, while the persistence for planning data and change documents are stored in SAP Datasphere, so that both systems are closely linked - without the effort of manual data transfers. Therefore, the solution might not be necessary if the SAC change documents are already stored in Datasphere.

 

The following steps outline the implementation of the solution.

In SAC, System – Administration – App Integration, create an OAuth client with Access to the Data Export Service.

 

 

In SAC, keep the OAuth Client URLs for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

 

In SAC, copy the OAuth Client ID and Client Secret for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

In Datasphere, in a space, create a Cloud Data Integration connection pointing to the SAC Data Export Service. The URL is in the format of

https://<your domain>/api/v1/dataexport/administration

 

In the connections management screen, validate the connection, and make sure the Data Flows feature is now enabled. It shall give the following message after validation on the connection.

Connection “SAC DES Change Docs” is valid. – Data flows are enabled. – Replication flows are not supported. – Remote tables are enabled.

 

In SAC, open the model with the Audit Data flag switched on, and note down the model ID in the rear part of the URL. For instance:

https://<your domain name>/sap/fpa/ui/app.html?sap-ui-theme=sap_belize#/modeler&/m/model/C4003n1icbi0loo9lvgv7t4pu41

 

In Datasphere, Data Builder- Create a Data Flow to load SAC audit logs into a target table.

  1. Use the model id to find the SAC source in the connection for the source node in the data flow.
  2. To make the daily backup more efficient, an exemplary expression implemented in the projection node can be: "Audit_Time" >= ADD_DAYS(NOW(), -1).
  3. To preserve the audit logs history that might be regularly cleaned in SAC, use Append mode on the target table for UPSERT.

 

 

 

In Datasphere, execute the data flow to load SAC audit logs and verify that the data is now present in Datasphere. Then, delete the audit logs in SAC, execute the data flow again to check that the audit logs history has been preserved after cleansing audit logs in SAC.

 

Last but not least, you may also develop an analytic model on top of the audit logs history table in Datasphere for analytics and build a report or visualization in SAC.

Note:

CDI connection type also supports the remote table as well as the data flow feature.

Remote table can use the following replication types, but none of those replications can well preserve the change document history.

  • Replication (snapshot)
  • Replication (real-time)

entry.title: Choosing the Right SAP Analytics Tool: Features, Benefits, and Strategy
entry.content:
Introduction : 

Within an organization's data and analytics strategy, SAP provides a portfolio of analytics solutions, including SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), and SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), each with a specific function. To assist clients in selecting the best option for their requirements, a comparative analysis of their salient characteristics and advantages is provided below.

SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics

Summary: This solution, which is directly integrated into the SAP S/4HANA ERP system, offers real-time analytics on operational data without requiring data replication.

Key Benefits :

  • Operational Reporting in Real Time: Get the most recent information straight from the ERP system.
  • Views of Core Data Services (CDS): For customizable reporting, use virtual data models.
  • Predefined KPIs and Dashboards: Use unconventional content to gain rapid insights.
  • Fiori-Based User Interface: Enhanced user experience through intuitive design.

Benefits:

  • Immediate Decision-Making: Facilitates quick actions based on current data.
  • Simplified Infrastructure: Eliminates the need for separate data warehousing solutions.
  • Seamless Integration: Embedded within the core ERP system, ensuring consistency.

 

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

Summary: A cloud-based platform combining business intelligence, planning, and predictive analytics, SAC connects to various data sources, including SAP and non-SAP systems.

Key Features:

  • Advanced Analytics: Utilize AI-driven insights and predictive modelling.
  • Planning Capabilities: Integrate financial planning and budgeting processes.
  • Collaboration Tools: Facilitate real-time discussions and decision-making.
  • Mobile Accessibility: Access analytics on-the-go through optimized dashboards.

Benefits:

  • Comprehensive Insights: Consolidates data from multiple sources for holistic analysis.
  • Enhanced Forecasting: Improves accuracy in planning and budgeting.
  • Scalability: Cloud infrastructure supports growth and flexibility.

 

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)

 Overview: A fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs SAP and third-party data, enabling advanced analytics and AI-driven insights across the organization.

Key Features:

  • Data Integration: Connects disparate data sources into a unified platform.
  • AI and ML Capabilities: Leverages machine learning for predictive analytics.
  • Prebuilt Applications: Offers industry-specific solutions and dashboards.
  • Data Governance: Ensures data quality and compliance across the organization.

Benefits:

  • Accelerated Decision-Making: Provides timely insights for informed decisions.
  • Reduced Complexity: Simplifies data management and analytics processes.
  • Enhanced Collaboration: Fosters cross-departmental data sharing and insights.

 

Comparative Study

Recommendation:

  • Choose SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics if your primary need is real-time, operational reporting directly within your ERP system, with minimal infrastructure overhead.

  • Opt for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) when you require advanced analytics, predictive modeling, and planning capabilities across various data sources, with a focus on scalability and collaboration.

  • Consider SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) if your organization seeks a unified platform for data integration, governance, and AI-driven insights, encompassing both SAP and third-party data sources.

Thank you for your time.  Stay connected for further updates on Analytics !

-With Warm Regards :  GIRI

entry.title: Use BTP destination service to call SAC multi-actions API
entry.content:
Based on the standard product document, this blog shows practical implementation steps to call SAC multi actions API from a BTP destination service that can be used in BTP CAPM service.

https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/user-propagation-via-saml-2-0-bearer-assertion-flow

 


1. In SAC System/Administration/App Integration, create an oAuth client with API Access and SAML2.0 Grant. Note down the Client ID and Secret. Some blogs say using Interactive Usage for the purpose, but the testing shows no return of SAC auth token.

 

 

2.  Note down oAuth2SAML Token URLs

 

3. Note down your SAC multi-action URL

 

4. In BTP Cockpit, create a BTP destination service that has a destination pointing to SAC oAuth Client and create a service key with a pair of client id and client credential. The service key is only used for Postman testing, but it’s unnecessary for the bound BTP app.

 

 

5. Download BTP signing certificate and IDP metadata from BTP destinations at sub account level. Kindly note that a destination service is created in dev space and bound with an BTP application.

 

 

6. In SAC, create a trusted identify provider maintained accordingly. The provider name should come from Entity ID of the downloaded IDP metadata and the signing certificate should come the downloaded trust from BTP destinations.

 

 

 

7. Add the userIdSource property to the BTP destination to allow passing the BTP access token attribute to SAC auth token.

 

 

 

8. Get a BTP access token using password credentials grant type.

 

 

 

9. Verify the BTP access token if it contains the email attribute.

 

 

 

 

10. Use the BTP access token to call BTP destination service to get a SAC auth token.

 

 

 

11. Use the SAC auth token to get a SAC CSRF token.

 

12. Use both the SAC auth token and SAC CSRF token to execute SAC multi-action.

13. Use the SAC auth token to get SAC multi-action execution status and verify it was successful.

14. How to allow BTP CAPM to use the destination service to call the SAC multi-action.

a. Update the package.json to have a reference to the BTP destination in the destination service that has been bound with the BTP app.

 

  "cds": {

    "requires": {

      "uaa": {

        "kind": "xsuaa"

      },

      "db": {

        "kind": "hana"

      },

      "CapExDestinationForUI": {

        "kind": "rest",

        "credentials": {

          "destination": "sac-multi-actions-dest_CLONING"

        },

        "csrf": {

          "method": "get",

 

 

          "url": "https://ps-trial.us10.hcs.cloud.sap/api/v1/csrf"

        }

      }

    }

  }

 

b. In a CAPM service event, connect to the destination and use POST method to call the multi action URL. It by default uses different Content-Type that might cause 415 Error, so pass application/json to overwrite the default to make sure it’s successful.

 

      let service = await cds.connect.to('CapExDestinationForUI');

      let projects = await service.tx(req).send("POST", "/multiActions/t.16:9C88BE058AA23F014E86756BBDB404D3/executions", req.data, { "Content-Type": "application/json" });

entry.title: Full-Page Fit vs. Scrollable Dashboards in SAC which one is better?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I'd like to discuss a common dilemma developers face when it comes to designing a dashboard in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).
Should I design the dashboard such that it fits entirely within the browser window (Full-Page Fit)? or should I design the dashboard such that it has a scroll? Would the customer be okay with having to scroll up and down to see the contents of the dashboard? 🙄

So, the design process begins even before we decide to click Create Story.
To Tackle this problem, I will be elaborating both the scenarios for you to make an informed decision while designing your next dashboard.

Difference between both the Dashboard Fit:

Assuming we are seeing the dashboard in a normal sized laptop screen [1366 x 768px] not a 1080p HD one. A Full-Page Fit Dashboard ensures all content is visible without scrolling, while a Scrollable Dashboard allows content to extend vertically or horizontally beyond the initial view, requiring user interaction to access additional information.

This choice significantly impacts user experience and performance. Both has its own advantages and disadvantages. Let's dive deep to understand the pros and cons of each type. 

Full-Page Fit Dashboard: (Everything visible in a single glance)

 Here in the above screenshot, see how all the KPIs presented within a single screen and there is no scroll to the right and bottom of the dashboards. This means that it is well within the boundaries of our 1366 x 768 px canvas.

Advantages

  • All KPIs are visible at a single glance, enabling quick decision-making.
  • No need to scroll, which is ideal for users who prefer a single-screen overview.

Disadvantages

  • Each KPI has less room, potentially less real estate and more congestion.
  • All widgets are triggered simultaneously, sending backend requests that can strain system resources.
  • Heavy widgets like tables may take longer to load, making the dashboard appear sluggish.

Performance Statistics

All the KPIs visible in viewport have triggered a backend request and rendered.

It's like going to a restaurant and saying bring me everything you have, even when you know you won't be able to eat everything they bring. Wasteful.👎

Total render time ~9.5s 

All the visible KPIs have triggered a backend request and are rendered at Frontend.

Dashboard with Scroll (You gotta scroll to see what you want)

 Scroll Section 1Scroll Section 2

Here in the above screenshot, see how we have a scroll to the right of the dashboard. This means that the KPIs are spaced out more and exceeds the page's default height of 768px, therefore the user would get a scroll when accessing the dashboard.

Advantages

  • More space per KPI allows for better viewability and detailed insights.
  • SAC’s viewport loading ensures only visible widgets are triggered, reducing initial load time and backend traffic.
  • Less frequently used or heavier components can be placed lower on the page.

Disadvantages

  • Users may miss the overall picture and need to scroll to compare KPIs.
  • Scrolling back and forth can hinder quick analysis and decision-making.

Performance Statistics

All the KPIs that has been viewed initially have triggered a backend request and rendered. The Un scrolled portion doesn't trigger any backend request neither doesn't render until we preview it.

This is like going to the restaurant and placing an order and post eating the main course you get to decide if you want to take on dessert. Only what is required is being consumed here. Resourceful 👍

Total render time ~8s

 Only KPIs visible during initial preview has been rendered

Finding the Middle Ground: Tab Strips

To balance usability and performance, developers can use Tab Strip.

These are container widgets used within a SAC story to organize content into separate, switchable tabs. They allow users to view different components, such as charts or tables, within a single application by providing a navigation area to select and display the content of each tab.

Tab strip - summary sectionTab strip - Table section

Here in the above screenshot, see how the dashboard is still fitted within the canvas and also having the benefits of loading what is required.

As we have also bifurcated the components into summary and table section. The heavier/Less frequently viewed KPIs are places in the subsequent tab strips, therefore reducing the initial load.

Benefits of Tab Strips

  • Essential KPIs are displayed upfront, while heavier or less frequently accessed components (e.g., raw data tables) are placed in separate tabs.
  • SAC’s default viewport loading ensures only visible components are triggered, reducing backend load and improving responsiveness.
  • Tabs offer a cleaner and better UI/UX.

Performance Statistics

Only the Default tab strip KPIs have triggered a backend request and has been rendered. The heavier KPIs which hasn't been previewed is still untriggered and unrendered.
Total render time ~7.5s

Only the Default tab strip KPIs have triggered a backend request and has been rendered

Key Principle: "What You See Is What Loads"

SAC's viewport optimization means that only the visible components are loaded initially. This explains why Full-Page Fit dashboards can be performance intensive as everything is triggered at once. In contrast, scrollable dashboards and tab-based layouts defer loading of non-visible components, enhancing performance.

However, it’s important to note that once a user navigates to hidden sections or tabs, those components will be triggered, potentially causing a brief delay.

Final Take away

The choice between a Full-Page Fit and a Scrollable Dashboard should be guided by user requirements and usage patterns. Developers must engage with users' early phases in the design process to understand:

  • Which KPIs are most frequently accessed?
  • Is a single-screen overview preferred?
  • Are users comfortable with scrolling or tab navigation?

I hope this article was helpful. Which one do you prefer? Let me know your doubts and opinions in the comments below!
